question.text: Two circular coils mounted parallel to each other on the same axis carry steady currents. If an observer between the coils reports that one coil is carrying a clockwise current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> while the other is carrying a counter-clockwise current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, then the two coils experience

solution.text: The coil carrying a current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></math> in clockwise sense coil has south polarity on that face of coil and other coil having current <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> in counter clockwise sense has north polarity on that face of the coil. As south and north poles will attract each other, hence a steady attractive force acts between the two coils.
